title: Isil faces the future without Baghdadi - one it has long planned for
text:
The death of Isil leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi came as a shock to his followers on Sunday, but not a surprise.

They had been meticulously planning for his demise for some time.

A fearsome ideologue who tried to spark a war of civilisation between Islam and the West, a man who created the most brutal terrorist group in modern history and ordered the genocide of the Yazidi people, Baghdadi’s legacy will not be forgotten in a hurry.

But he spawned something much bigger that will likely outlive him.

As one Isil fighter I spoke to in an interview from his cell in Syria earlier this year put it: “We are fighting for Allah and the Islamic State, not for any temporary earthly leader.”

For years Baghdadi’s high profile had made it difficult for the leader to actually lead. His strict security made it impossible to communicate with supporters, aside from him sporadic and brief audio messages.

Nor, by all accounts, was he involved in any of the group's day-to-day operations. The loss of Isil’s territory in March stripped him of the last of the trappings of his self-appointed role of caliph and made him little more than a fugitive in the desert.
